posts.name: Brendan R.
posts.cooked:
We have a new (less than a month old) LimeLight 3G that we recently connected to our robot. It is powered via Rev’s POE injector cable which is connected directly to the second port of our robot’s old radio (not the new Vivid-Hosting one). Whenever the robot shakes (such as when it is accelerating very fast), it temporarily drops from the network, usually for about 3-5 mins.

We tried shaking the robot by hand while it was disabled and this issue still occurred, so we know it is not an electrical brownout issue from power being drawn by motors. We have also shaken the radio by hand and it didn’t occur, so we know it is not related to the radio vibrating as well. By checking the limelight’s ‘heartbeat’ ( hb on networktables), we are able to confirm that the limelight is only disconnecting from the network, and not completely power cycling.

Has anyone had any issues like this, or have any suggestions? I’d hate to have to send it back.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked:
Two things to suggest with a problem like this:

Check the network cable and (to test) replace it with one you know to be good. It may be that the cable has a break or other internal problem that causes one of the wires to not be connected when under high stress like shaking. This might well not interrupt the power to the Limelight, but cause the network signal to be disrupted.

Make sure you aren’t just experiencing a disconnect problem at the network connectors. Get them seated properly, test that the Limelight is working correctly, then hot glue the connectors into place (on everything: the Limelight, the POE injector, the radio). This may well solve a problem like this where, just as above, a slightly loose connection might not cause the power to be cut off, but will interrupt the network signal.

Those are my two cents on this. Most likely to be something simple like this, though it is remotely possible that there’s something loose inside the Limelight. Hopefully you can solve this without having to return it.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: I doubt this is what it is, but we and many others have issues with the second port in firmware and that’s just a quick thing to consider. Have you tried isolating the limelight by connecting it directly to your laptop and shaking the limelight?

Does your ethernet port on the 3G actually “click” when a cable is connected? Do you hot glue your connections?

There’s not all that much inside a limelight, so I’d be surprised if the solder connections internally are damaged. I’d be more willing to think the clip retention on the rj45 port maybe got damaged or bent and isn’t holding your cable properly. Could be bent pins in the port as well.

Hot glue is a friend, but you can also reach out to Limelight for help.

FWIW we always power our Limelights directly from PDH or Mini PDH , personally not a fan of just POE.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
Akash_Rastogi:

FWIW we always power our Limelights directly from PDH or Mini PDH , personally not a fan of just POE.

We used the mini power module in testing and that was great but just pdh/pdp ports are the least points of failure and therefore probably best

The old radios have issues with the second port not working properly with the main network. I can’t say exactly what the issue is that causes this, but the common workaround is to plug the main radio port into an unmanaged network switch on the robot and run all other network devices off of it.
I’d recommend putting a network switch on your bot as well. The second port (in my experience) rarely works.
